cards.front: CB configuration: which terminal gets input?
cards.back: Emitter is input, Collector is output, Base is common (AC ground).

cards.front: CC configuration: which terminal gives output?
cards.back: Emitter is output, Base is input, Collector is common (to V_CC).
A_V ≈ g_m·R_C (non-inverting). Same magnitude as CE but NO sign inversion.
A_V ≈ 1 (voltage follower). Output "follows" input with slight offset of V_BE.
R_in ≈ r_e = V_T/I_C ≈ 25Ω at 1mA. Very low — matches low-impedance sources.
R_out ≈ r_e = V_T/I_C ≈ 25Ω. Very low — drives low-impedance loads easily.

cards.front: Why does CB have no Miller effect?
cards.back: C_BC connects output to ground (base), not input. No feedback capacitance multiplication. Better high-freq response.
A_I = α = β/(β+1) ≈ 0.99. CB provides voltage gain but NOT current amplification.
A_I = β + 1 ≈ 101. Higher than CE (β). CC is the best current amplifier among BJT configs.

cards.front: When to use CE vs CB vs CC?
cards.back: CE: general-purpose high gain. CB: high-frequency/RF. CC: buffer/impedance matching. Often cascade: CE → CC.
